text: Welcome, John Boyk, PhD, to the fourth Active Inference Symposium.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We're really pleased to have you here and looking forward to your session, Cognar Ecosystem, Facilitating Group Cognition at Scale.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And over to you.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: All right.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Thanks, Ian.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: um again my name is john boyk i'm a fellow at the activist institute active inference institute um and i will be talking about a the cognar ecosystem to to facilitate cognition at scale as ian said uh i do want to say that the links for this there's a bunch of links on the institute project page
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Uh, I think, I think these slides will eventually be made public, but in the meantime, if you're interested, you can just simply search on Cognar and CODA or Cognar in my last name, Boyk, and you'll find, uh, the Institute project page.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: There's lots of links there.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: All right.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So what is the Cognar ecosystem?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Uh, Cognar means cognitive narrative and in concept it's, uh, it's an open source online extensible ecosystem, uh, technologies, tools, libraries,
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: facilitate group cognition especially for large groups and although there are many many use cases uh the the use case that's that one of the prime use cases is deliberation strategizing collective problem solving and decision making in the large group setting
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Cognar essentially helps, what I like to say is it helps users to tell their story.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: That is, convey their beliefs to a group about how the world works relative to some situation.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And even more specifically, convey their belief model to a group.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Make the belief model explicit and transparent to the group.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So they might answer or address questions like, what's the problem or situation?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: What happened?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: How did it happen?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: What might happen next?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Why did it happen?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Who does it affect?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Who is involved?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: What does it mean?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: What should be done?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: What can be learned?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: All of these kinds of questions.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Um, Cognar allows P allows users to tell a rich story and by rich, I mean, potentially long, complex, nuanced, dynamic, conditional, uh, uh, um, quite different.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: quite in comparison quite different from some kind of online collaborative architecture that for example asks you to a yes or no question or asks you to give a thumbs up or thumbs down on some issue
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Cognar will allow a user to convey very rich information.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And there's a backend computational system that assists the digestion of that information so that the group can better understand the many different stories.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So the computational system assists and guides users in construction stories, helps the group digest the information, make sense of it, assesses stories for their quality, you know, is the story on topic, is it comprehensible, that kind of thing.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then the backend system also performs inference for queries that various group members might have about a story or for a storyteller.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: It is important to say that the computational system does not predict the future.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: That is, if the issue at hand, say, is garbage collection in a local community, the computational system is not going to assess stories and then predict which of them is most realistic.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: That's not really its purpose.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: What its purpose is, is to convey, to make transparent and explicit the beliefs of members.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And the members, when they create their story, when they tell their story, they include what they think will happen in the future.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The users make predictions.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And also the group assesses the realism of any of the stories that are submitted.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So what is a Cognar group?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: A group is a set of people that sense their world, process information, anticipate outcomes, evaluate options, make decisions.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And in other words, we can think of a group as an organism that performs cognition.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Um, and then the question is how, what, what design of Cognar might actually facilitate functional cognition as opposed to dysfunctional cognition.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So examples of groups could be, you know, every, uh, group, uh, informal group who like polka dot shirts, uh, a social club, volunteer groups, civic organizations, professional groups, corporations, nonprofits, political entities, such as cities and more.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So groups can range from formal to informal, flexible to structured, temporary to permanent, small to large, autocratic to democratic.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The platform is really a tool that can be used for many use cases by many kinds of groups for many purposes.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: There are, of course, some rules to keep it all functional and transparent.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And when I say large group, what does that mean?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Often in the literature, when they talk about large group deliberation and cognition, they might be thinking of dozens of people.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But here we're thinking about perhaps dozens, hundreds, thousands, millions.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: This should scale up to cities, states, and perhaps even a nation.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Who knows?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: I should say, if Cognar were ever built, if it works as advertised, this is all possible.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And maybe I should also say at the moment, I've posted two articles on Cognar so far, two research articles, and that's all that's been done.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this is at the beginning.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: This is a vision, really, of what this could be.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: I'm presenting a vision.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Um, so the question is what kind of design for Cognar would allow some large groups, say a hundred thousand people to, to, to, um, gather online synchronously or asynchronously and share the potentially complex dynamic beliefs, belief models about some situation.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: How could that be done?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: That's the question here.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And obviously, I have some ideas on how that could be done.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But first, maybe I should say that the Cognar project is inspired by active inference.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And in particular, active inference, from my
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: from the vantage point of this project active inference provides a description of functional cognition that is as i think everyone probably knows by now is watching watching the seminar that that cognition we can idealize it as a maybe a four-part cyclic process of predict act sense and learn and and it involves many components for example memory recall attention
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: um and this the entire picture of that process can be um you know as it plays out in a human or an agent it could be either functional or dysfunctional for example uh an an agent that that that cannot predict the future with accuracy is going to make decisions that are sub-optimal in general you know typically
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So that would be an example of dysfunctional cognition.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: If you can't remember what happened or you can't predict accurately what's going to happen in the future, those would all be indicative of dysfunctional cognition.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So in active inference, an agent favors choices that ensure the greatest resolution of uncertainty under the constraints as preferred outcomes are realized.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And all of that provides a framework such that the components of cognition could be recognized.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And each component can be focused on as a design element, and the process of cognition in any group could be assessed, whether that is functional or dysfunctional or somewhere in between.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And of course, that would be a multivalued scale.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So what is Cognar really?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Cognar essentially is designed to be part of the cognitive architecture of the group that is using it.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Any organism that performs cognition has some kind of cognitive architecture
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: For an animal, that involves a nervous system.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: For a human, it can involve external objects such as computers and tools.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And for a group, it includes a set of norms, rules, mechanisms, institutions, sensors, analytic processes, systems, and any other procedures that facilitate or guide cognition.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then Cognar is obviously
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: designed to be a component of the cognitive architecture of the group that uses it.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And viewed differently, and I'll talk about this more in a moment,
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Cognar technology provides a means to digitize and make explicit a person or an agent's belief model.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And in that sense, some of the technology behind Cognar could be used far beyond Cognar.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: It could be used in medicine, psychology, and unlimited number of other applications of how you would take an agent or a person's belief model
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: make that explicit in a way that computation can occur and include that into some kind of inference models or generative models.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So Cognar stems from some past work that I've done
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And Cognar and this past work are related in that all of it is about cognitive architectures.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: In the past work, I was looking at social systems as cognitive architectures.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And by social systems, I mean economic systems, financial systems, governance systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: i view those core societal systems as the as a means as a as a part of the cognitive architecture architecture of the society that is using them that is we we think through our governance systems we think through our economic systems we make decisions that that affect our world through our economic system for example
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And the previous projects asked this question.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Out of all conceivable societal systems designs, and I don't mean conceivable in capitalism and socialism and the way it's been implemented in the past.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: What I mean is like blank slate.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Out of all conceivable designs for economic financial governance systems, which ones might be most fit for purpose?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And that purpose is cognition in the active inference set.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So reduction of uncertainty, accurate prediction of the future, attaining those conditions that allow for thriving of the population, those things.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And I propose in this past work a path really of how such a project could be implemented, what it would do, how it would go, how would you test new systems,
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: um and so on so i refer to this earlier work and again the links are all on the cognar project page if you can find that all right so what is uh the maybe the core element of cognar is um what i call a story graph and essentially it's a meaning representation it's the it's the explicit representation of a user's belief model
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And this, of course, is a very difficult problem to solve.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: How do you take some belief model that is in, say, the mind of a person and put that down on paper, so to speak, such that computation can occur with it, inference can occur with it?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: This is a very tough problem, but I think there's possible ways to move forward with it.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: I think I mentioned, or I should mention, that there was two papers published on Cognar.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The first paper is more of an introduction overview.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The second paper is really all about, it focuses on the potential meaning representations.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So StoryGraph is the sort of the core innovation on which Cognar is based and its StoryGraphs are used to curate, understand, reason with, you know, conduct inference on high quality information about human experiences, beliefs, and expectations.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And essentially the way it works is a user might type in or say some passage, a few sentences perhaps, a thought, and that passage would be translated into what I call a story graph fragment, just a small little graph, a meaning graph.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And that little fragment would then, the system would merge that fragment into the growing story graph, the overall story graph.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then eventually by inputting passages after passages after passages, the story graph gets built up, the meaning representation gets built up.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then once it's complete or once it's almost complete, then it can be translated into alternative meaning representations that might be appropriate for various logical models or other kinds of models, probabilistic models.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: and maybe be translated more directly into some types of probabilistic models and could also be translated into a natural language so in in time eventually you know if Cognar is successful over time it should be possible to have the system read back your story like tell me tell me you know read this back to me and let me make sure that it's what I think what I'm intending it to be
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Uh, even, uh, you know, in the far future, it might be possible to make animations as an output of this, you know, this, a little movie of this is what I think happened.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And this is what I think will happen in the future.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So, what is a meaning representation?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: I have a picture here of an abstract meaning representation.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: That's a very common one used in the research world.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: In natural language inference, in the research world, there's lots of different types of meaning representations.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: This is just one of them I'm using as an example.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And this is for a story, excuse me, a sentence.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: A similar technique is almost always impossible to apply to other crops such as cotton, soybeans, and rice.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And you can just, I won't go into detail about this, but you can kind of see that there's a graph and various words are connected to each other.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Ideas are connected to each other.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Concepts are connected to each other.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: and this kind of meaning representation is used throughout research and the story graph you can think of the story graph as a much more complex version of this it consists of layers you know one layer might be predictions that the story is making about the future you know that could be one
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: uh layer um but a story graph is actually more like instead of it's sort of static picture like this static graph a story graph is really more like a movie it's a evolving graph path really and and it involves high dimensional vectors of word meaning so there's it's far more complicated than this but this gives you a really rough idea of what I'm after
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Cognar has many use cases.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: If Cognar were successful, it could be ubiquitous in social life.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So a group, again, could be all kinds of different groups, many different groups.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: defines a group event, its topic, its purpose, how decisions were made for this event, what kind of methods and rules would be used.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The group then invites people to participate and communications for this group event could be many to many, many to one, one to many.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: I have examples of all of these in the paper, but I'll go over a couple shortly.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Use cases could be decision-making, customer service, emergency reports, public polling, instructions on how to build a shelf or something, how to run a machine, system descriptions of how this system works, educational use cases, and more.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And the later versions of Cognar could include role-playing strategizing.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Um, you know, here's what I believe.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Here's what I think this, my, my competitor believes, and I'm gonna do this, you know, how, what would my competitor do if I did this or, you know, all kinds of various versions of stride.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: How do I get the girl?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Should I, should I wear a suit and tie?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Should I wear jeans?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: How should I act?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: You know, like whatever the, whatever the, the, the issue is at hand.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So I, this is an example use case for decision-making that I've, I've written out a little text here, but obviously this, again, this would be passages that a user is inputting into the system and, um, and a graph is being created, you know, as passages are implemented.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this person says, you know, whatever this issue X is, we better first address issue Y that caused X.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And issue Y started when blank and it has the effect of blank.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And if we don't solve Y, then we can't solve A. And this is likely to occur if that happens.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And, you know, just on and on and on about some kind of conditional story, complex conditional story.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And in this kind of setting where it's group decision-making, what could occur is that at the top of this graph here, story input and editing, there could be 10,000 users or something, 10,000 members of this group.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: They each create their story.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And the system would be helping them create the story too to make it easy.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then after, say, the first round of input, the system would perform a bunch of computations, assess what the variety of different stories are, report back on how stories cluster with each other and all kinds of other things, story quality and story components and all kinds of things so that the group can better understand what the picture of all these stories is.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then there would be opportunity for group dialogue, feedback, story digestion, asking questions, users asking questions about different other people's stories.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then after that is finished, then we can go back to the beginning and users see everyone's story and all the results of assessments.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then maybe they want to change their story to reflect what has been said.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Maybe I'm involved in this group, and I put down my story, and then I eventually get to see what other people are saying, and I think, oh, that's a good idea.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: I want to include that piece in mine.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: I like that, or I don't like this, or I'm going to comment on this part of this guy's story.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So over a series of rounds, the idea is, hopefully,
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: that the belief of the group would start to coalesce around core models.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Maybe one person's story really captures the group sentiment, or maybe the group as a whole, the synthesis of their stories captures the group sentiment.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And over a series of rounds, the thinking of the group, the belief model of the group starts to coalesce around central themes.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then there could be voting at the end, various kinds of voting would be possible.
